topic.title: Man Tried to Burn Down Telecoms Watchdog to Avenge Pirate Site-Blocking
topic.body:
A man in Russia who admitted to attempting three arson attacks says he took action in response to the authorities blocking pirate sites. The prosecutor demanded two years in prison but the man, who tried to burn down the offices of telecoms watchdog Roscomnadzor, has now received 18 months probation.  [...read more](https://torrentfreak.com/man-tried-to-burn-down-telecoms-watchdog-to-avenge-pirate-site-blocking-190817/#disqus_thread)

Priceless!!!

topic.title: Why does ZeroTorrent have more functionality than ZeroTalk?
topic.body:
While it appears that ZeroTorrent(http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroTorrent.bit) was originally a clone of ZeroTalk, the site has added functionality such as categories and even a search ability. I'm just curious as to why nofish or some other competent developer hasn't integrated some of these changes into ZeroTalk so when new users decide to clone the forum for their own use, they aren't left without search, categories, or other improvements.

Just my two cents as finding anything on ZeroTalk is extremely frustrations to the point that it is a put off.

1558266064_1DUHekDkg6jJxQKGvAY2Hni5yNdTQ.body:
Zeronet is not widely popular for a combination of reasons. While I'm sure I will miss some but here are a few reasons as to why Zeronet will likely never have a huge popularity spark.

1. Zeronet has an expansion problem. While I'm sure it's not a dead end but when sites begin to have hundreds of thousands of peers and seeders who are active, last I read syncing the updates is going to prove problematic.

2. The 'darknet' carries a social taboo. Mainly due to the lack of centralised control over the networks by the governing bodies.

3. As hinted prior. The governments and regulators would rather loosen their control over society just a little bit to squash the opposition and fans of darknet usage rather than have the majority of society adopt said uncontrollable technology.

4. Zeronet has a steep learning curve. If you don't have a basic understanding of HTML, Javascript, and CSS. You're not going to create anything really special here.

5. Lack of content. The network is still relatively new. Many sites have zero seeders many sites have unseeded content.

6. The zeronet network is still attempting to find it's purpose. I haven't seen any viable marketplaces or currency exchange sites. I haven't seen any long lasting music portals to which development hasn't been abandoned and said sites now stand more as a proof of concept rather than a typical portal of today's standards and expectations.

Now don't get me wrong, Zeronet is a godsend for the persistence of communication and has potential. But a mass influx of users would be more toxic rather than beneficial at this stage of development. The world doesn't need nor want another TOR 2.0. And Zeronet will not become popular advertising itself as one.

1565658736_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5.body:
> What I don't understand yet is how long Joe can wait before coming back online, before his page can no longer be accessed while he's offline

So long at least one other visitor has left their PC on or running a VPS instance to receive the incoming updates, the unprocessed updates can be compiled indefinitely until that user's Site Size Limit has been exceeded. 

> What if one million people send messages, causing many megabytes of data to just "live in the ether"

The messages wouldn't 'live in the ether', upon the visitor loading the site on a first visit, they would be prompted to increase the site storage limit as it has been exceeded. If the visitor chooses not to do this, the user should not be able to add any posts as there is no addition space left for their saved comment. If the user does extend the Storage Limit for that site, they would be able to post their comment, but unless others also increase their site limits, the site will fail to propagate to those who choose not to, or are unable to at that specific time, to extend the site storage limit.

> But at the same time, there must be a longer "grace period" since nobody can be expected to be online all the time and servers are very problematic for a number of reasons (whether at home or in a data center)...

Not true,, I've been running a Zeronet node in a VPS for over a year now to help seed various KopyKate videos and other zeronet content that I am fond of. Sure it had to have some restarts but the focus is more on redundancy. If I have a Zeronet VPS, and You have a Zeronet VPS out of hobby, and Joe has a Zeronet VPS out of research, those three VPS combined have enough up time to keep most material available well enough to supply a barrage of hit-&-run visitors. (Given the condition that all three VPS users are sharing the same social site or popular content)

1567130399_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qk.body:
From my understanding TOR:Available  means your Zeronet client can communicate with other zeronet clients that are set to TOR:Strict & TOR:Available. This is a benefit for the network as the TOR:Available client will allow TOR:Strict clients to communicate with TOR:Unavailable clients by using the TOR:Available client as a proxy for data transmission.

Otherwise it uses non tor communication for file-transfers and tracker lookups. If the user has a desire for the tracker connections to be masked or proxy, that can be done in the zeronet configuration with a tor or http proxy.

__Correct procedure to delete a zeronet site:__
To be able to delete created sites, you have to open your '0' side bar while visiting that site, Uncheck "This is my site", then you can click the Delete button, then select the option to either delete the site (or to blacklist it) to remove the site from your zeronet client.

Many times the "you cannot delete your own site" message appears simply because that person has "This is my site" checked and the removal denial is a precautionary measure against the removal of owned sites by accident.

> [dmd](#comment_13_1DtDb2LXvnxGVkpuNv9CEeBnpcB6sqTZb1): I am sorry you are having to answer the same question over and over again, but it is only going to get worse. 


To copy almost any zeronet site, simply browse to the site, pull open the Right '0' and then click the small text that reads 'OPEN SITE DIRECTORY"

This will take you to the local file path on yoru pc that contains the website data that you are viewing.

To make a copy, simply create a new empty site on zeronet, goto that sites file path by using the "OPEN SITE DIRECTORY" clickable text, and then copy the data from the site you want to copy to the site you just created.

Now you will be able to modify the site's files and sign & publish the site as you are the owner. Of course this get's complicated when concerning merger sites like ZeroMe and social sites that are riddled with comments.

'Cloning' is a feature that can be enabled by the site creator by altering that site's content.json file by altering the values of

 "clone_root": "",
 "cloneable": true,

Where root points to a copy of the site before any extra user data has been added.(Like copying a social site but without the user comments)

I will admit that one large drawback from the expansion of Zeronet is the learning curve and lack of documentation that developers must overcome.

PS thanks GitCenter, I didn't notice your reply before mine

> [dmd](#comment_16_1DtDb2LXvnxGVkpuNv9CEeBnpcB6sqTZb1): I get a "Content publish failed" error.

As gitcenter stated, this is because nobody else besides you is seeding your site, so it can't be published to anyone.
The message will go away once your site has other people seeding it which will happen once you share the link on social forums and make it popular.

> [trustedleanings](#comment_7_1MfahbRQx2DvKRccN57nhFZvYmfirQfZeX): if i'm seeding other peoples shady content? I didn't sign it, am I really responsible for it?

Yes, but just use some damn common sense. Browsing Zeronet is no more dangerous than browsing the TOR network or even some really shady porn sites on the clearnet. Not many people browse the internet properly and decide to let their browsers store their browsing cache for extended periods of time which makes them just as liable as hosting illegal content on zeroent.

Sure TOR is great at keeping your identity private both on zeronet and the clearnet, but the point is just use common sense. One thing I have noticed on Zeronet is that the pedos are quite meticulous at properly naming and identifying the material they share, so it is a bit difficult to stumble upon it unless you go looking for it. (Blindly clicking on every site in ZeroSites for example)

But yes, if you are the owner of a piece of hardware that is making available illegal content, you will likely be responsible. The question is one of are you willing to stand up for your right to share said material. As there are grey areas such as sharing educational films for educational purposes.

TL:DR Yes, you are responsible, but every tool has it beneficial uses and associated dangers.
Just don't be that girl trying to take a selfie near a cliff and you will fine.

1568982640_1D9mg5Mzk96FBLEkjCxabcydfY4Bb.body: I sent you 0.03 NMC to the address you specified which is enough to register a domain. You're welcome.

> [filips](#comment_213_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Also, for how long, in years, I will be able to renew domain with 0.03 NMC?

Once you register the domain and added the json tag needed for zeronet to identify the domain entry the registration is indefinite, additional subdomains can be added by updating the json entry for that domain which will cost more NMC each time a request is sent. So make sure there are no mistakes in the original json entry as the FIRST_UPDATE is free.

I'm the owner of the blocklist.bit domain and here is what the json entry looks like to register the subdomains of the main zeronet users who have published one. Feel free to use this as an example. There is also an example on the [ZeroNames](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F/) site.

1569172866_1LQUzLxUdiuVZKwr7wiqii7GzGs8i.body:
When I migrate my users.json to a new zeronet instance, here is my procedure that works for linux & windows

  - Ensure your prior user.json from your /data/ zeroent directory is safe and secured. And shut down that zeronet instance.
  - Install a new instance of zeronet, then launch it so the data folder can be created, then Shut down Zeronet
  - Copy the users.json file to the /data/ directory of the new zeronet instance.
  - Launch Zeronet then visit the ZeroID provider.
  - After the initial loading of the ZeroID archive files it should say your are authenticated without submitting a new ID.

If you want to backup / import your prior list of zeronet sites be sure to include sites.json in the same procedure.

Best of luck.

Let's take a fun scenario of probabilities to see why zeronet has so few users.

  - How many people are upset with their current social media network to seek an alternative?
  - Of those remaining, how many will be able to overcome the mainstream taboo of "Only pedophiles and hackers use darknets"
  - Of those remaining, how many will choose to seek a darknet alternative rather than some other clearnet social site.
  - Of those remaining, how many are aware that there are more darknet choices other than just TOR and continue to choose zeronet and not freenet or some other darknet alternative.
  - Of those remaining, how many are technically capable enough to install or understand the basics of zeronet.
  - Of those remaining, how many will stick with the network rather than decide to no longer visit it for one reason or another.
  - Of those remaining, how many reside in the same language based community as you do?
  - Of those remaining, how many will choose to announce their activities , actions, or presence to the darknet community.

This doesn't even consider how burdensome zeronet is for strict mobile users. It gets to a point where the fraction of people remaining are so small that only a few handfuls of people will seemingly make it to the public scene.

1572732591_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
From what I understand of Bitchute when it was first launched was that it was a hybrid of youtube in that the videos would be seeded by a central server, but the service had the capability to have peers distribute the video to other peers who may be viewing the same video to conserve server bandwidth and was ultimately a working proof of concept to lower expenses. It's been many years later and I would consider the service vaguely popular.

Zeronet on the other hand does not have one server that is operated by one entity. I would consider Zeronet to be more redundant in that if BitChute decided to throw in the towel, their platform, and the videos the users host would eventually result in a 404 error while Zeronet distribution nodes will last as long as those interested to preserve the media continue to seed it for others. Similar to how torrent swarms operate. Someone's non-profit generosity serves the benefit to others for a small request that they do the same.

Kopy.Kate.Big has a hard coded file limit on the number of uploads a user can preform.
You can meet your file limit at KK and not be able to publish any more,  but still be able to post comments at other places.

A solution is to remove junk data from your content and data.json files in your folder on KK as when deleting files from the KK interface does not remove the meta data from your content files. (Don't forget to sign your file before the site updates them with the old data) && (Caution is advised as a corrupted file would render all of your uploads as unlisted.) 1576787090_1T4nUY5eDwwMk3zFjh27ZQCqkVpPx.body:
Bootstrapper is meant for Zeronet clients that are ran 24 / 7 such as those found on a VPS. The plugin will turn your client into a tracker which will allow other zeronet clients that have trouble communicating with standard trackers will be able to communicate with your client.

It can be enabled by navigating to the plugin folder and renaming it from disabled-Bootstrapper to Bootstrapper and then launching zeronet

On your ZeroHello, go to the Top Right and click on trackers and your IP will be listed on the Tracker List for peers to connect to you.

Note: The priority is by peer up time meaning your IP will be the last one or two listed of the list while those up the longest will be listed first.

just take a look at the plugin folder, they are pretty self descriptive.

Otherwise nothing is really of importance unless you run your client from a remote server.

1577737812_12BRJSQrTETJVZzt2jHdqPywv3Sdu.body:
About four years ago I started to vape as an alternative to smoking cigarettes for 20 years. I did that for about two years until my lymph node on my neck got swollen and wouldn't go down. I went to an ENT for an examination and he couldn't give me an prognosis of what caused it without a biopsy because much like other exposures to chemicals; vaping, the metals used for the coil, the additive, and chemicals used for the dyes and flavoring were not yet regulated nor given any long term studies.

I pretty much stopped cold turkey from vaping with nicotine and flavorings and went through withdrawal for about 3 months and the lump on my neck went back to the normal size after 7 months later, it's been two years since then and I haven't had any desire to vape even without nicotine simply because there are just too many uncertainties in the manufacturing process of the coil & juices.

I knew something was up after it was more difficult to breath from a year of vaping compared to 20 years of smoking.
